After starting his career in the youth set-up at [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]], Cleverley joined Manchester United at the age of 12. Between 2007 and 2009 he played for Manchester United's reserve team, and occasionally in first-team [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly match]]es. Cleverley was [[Loan (sports)|loaned]] to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] at the start of 2009, for whom he made his first [[English Football League|Football League]] appearances, helping the team secure the League One title and promotion to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]]. He spent the [[2009–10 Watford F.C. season|2009–10 season]] on loan with Watford in the Championship, where he scored 11 goals in 33 league matches and was voted as their [[Watford F.C. Player of the Season|Player of the Season]]. On 31 August 2010, he joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a season-long loan, where he scored four goals in 25 appearances and helped them to avoid relegation on the final day of the season. He returned to Manchester United for the start of the [[2011–12 Manchester United F.C. season|2011–12 season]] and made his first competitive appearance in the [[FA Community Shield]] victory against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. He won the Premier League with Manchester United in 2013. Cleverley played for [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain]] at the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Summer Olympics]], and later that year made his debut for the [[England national football team|England national team]]. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Cleverley was born in [[Basingstoke]], Hampshire, but grew up in [[Bradford]], West Yorkshire.{{cite web |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=Dream debut for Tom |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2008/Jul/Dream-debut-for-Tom.aspx |publisher=Manchester United |page=1 |date=26 July 2008 |accessdate=16 January 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012214131/http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2008/Jul/Dream-debut-for-Tom.aspx |archivedate=12 October 2012 |deadurl=no}} He went to [[Hanson School]].{{cite web |title=Famous Students |url=http://www.hansonoldstudents.org/links/ |publisher=Hanson Old Students Association |accessdate=15 January 2019 }} He was part of [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City's]] youth set-up, but joined [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] as an 11-year-old trainee in July 2000.{{cite news|title=Tom Cleverley exclusive: Why I was right to leave Manchester United and Everton|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/08/25/tom-cleverley-exclusive-right-leave-manchester-united-everton/|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=25 August 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} During the 2005–06 season, he made nine appearances for the under-18 team. He also received a taste of reserve team football when he was named on the bench for the team's 4–1 away win over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 21 February 2006.{{cite news|title=Manchester United's Wonderkid – Tom Cleverley: Do You Know Him?|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/2292/editorials/2011/08/08/2610406/manchester-uniteds-wonderkid-tom-cleverley-do-you-know-him|publisher=Goal.com|date=8 August 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} His first appearance for the reserves came in a 0–0 away draw to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] almost a year later, on 15 February 2007, by which time he had become a regular in the under-18 team. However, just over a month later, he suffered a long-term injury and was ruled out for seven months.{{cite news|title=United kids can make Paul proud|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/united-kids-can-make-paul-989648|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=26 April 2007|accessdate=16 August 2016}} He returned to action in October 2007, playing for the reserves in a 1–1 home draw with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. The 2007–08 season marked Cleverley's emergence as a regular in the Manchester United reserve team, making 21 appearances as the team went on to win both the [[Manchester Senior Cup]] and the [[Lancashire Senior Cup]], in which he scored in the final against Liverpool.{{cite news|title=Glory for young Reds|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/glory-for-young-reds-962573|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=19 April 2010|accessdate=16 August 2016}} He also scored his first goals in a Manchester United shirt on 23 January 2008, when he scored both of United's goals in a 2–0 away win over Bolton Wanderers in the [[Premier Reserve League]]. His consistent performances for the reserves earned him the captaincy of the team in the absence of regular captain [[Sam Hewson]], as well as a nomination for the Denzil Haroun Reserve Player of the Year award – he lost out to [[Richard Eckersley (footballer)|Richard Eckersley]]. In recognition of his performances for the reserves, on 24 July 2008, Cleverley was called up to the Manchester United first team for the remainder of their tour of South Africa and the match against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in Nigeria.{{cite news |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=Trio join senior squad |accessdate=12 November 2008}} ===Loan spells=== ====Leicester City==== On 16 January 2009, Cleverley joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the 2008–09 season and was given the number 7 shirt.{{cite news |title=United Midfielder Joins Foxes |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~1522804,00.html |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=16 January 2009 |accessdate=16 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913050839/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~1522804%2C00.html |archivedate=13 September 2012 }} He made his debut on 19 January 2009 in a 2–0 away win over [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]], coming on as an 85th-minute substitute for [[Matty Fryatt]].{{cite news |title=Yeovil 0–2 Leicester |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7816036.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 January 2009 |accessdate=19 January 2009}} Cleverley scored his first Leicester City goal few weeks later on 3 February 2009, in a 4–1 win over [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]].{{cite news|title=Walsall 1–4 Leicester City|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7869349.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 February 2009|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley then scored his second goal for the club on 7 March 2009, in a 4–0 win over [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]].{{cite news|title=Match report: Leicester City 4–0 Cheltenham Town|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/city-verdict-impressive-display-fires-clear-warning-chasing-pack/story-12065076-detail/story.html|newspaper=Leicester Mercury|date=7 March 2009|accessdate=16 August 2016}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} After two goals in 15 matches for Leicester, Cleverley's loan spell came to a premature end after he suffered a season-ending shoulder injury against [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]].{{cite news|title=Anxious wait for Tom Cleverley|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/anxious-wait-cleverley/story-12048221-detail/story.html|newspaper=Leicester Mercury|date=23 March 2009|accessdate=16 August 2016}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He then returned to Manchester United for treatment and underwent surgery on his shoulder on 2 April 2009.{{cite web |title=Cleverley sends message to fans |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~1607650,00.html |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=31 March 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403172603/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~1607650,00.html |archivedate=3 April 2009 |deadurl=yes}} Although his loan had ended, Cleverley was presented with a medal on 24 April after Leicester secured their promotion as champions of [[EFL League One|League One]].{{cite web |title=Champions picture special |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~1638777,00.html |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=25 April 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2009 [[James Chester]] and [[Corry Evans]], Cleverley was nominated by Manchester United reserve team manager [[Ole Gunnar Solskjær]] for the Denzil Haroun Reserve Player of the Year award.{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Bostock |title=Reserve Player of the Year |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/Reserves/Reserves-News/2009/Apr/Reserve-Player-of-the-Year.aspx |publisher=Manchester United |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} ====Watford==== After being featured and scored in the pre–season [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly match]] against [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], Cleverley was told by [[Alex Ferguson]] that he would be loaned out to gain further first-team experience.{{cite news|title=Cleverley's a wanted man|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cleverleys-a-wanted-man-926542|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=7 August 2009|accessdate=16 August 2016}} On 18 August 2009, Cleverley signed for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on loan, and was able to play in their match away to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] that evening.{{cite news |title=Watford seal Cleverley loan deal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/watford/8206810.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=18 August 2009}} He started the match and was booked within four minutes of the start of the second half, but then sealed a 4–2 win with a goal in the second minute of injury time at the end of the match.{{cite news |title=Nottingham Forest 2–4 Watford|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8195606.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=18 August 2009}} He then scored another goal on his home debut four days later, scoring Watford's second goal in a 2–2 draw with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]],{{cite news |title=Watford 2–2 Blackpool |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8202363.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 August 2009 |accessdate=22 August 2009}} and became Watford's joint-top scorer with the second goal in a 2–0 win over [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in November.{{cite news |title=Watford 2–0 Preston |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8341219.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 November 2009 |accessdate=7 November 2009}} Shortly afterwards, he extended his loan deal at Watford until the end of the [[2009–10 Watford F.C. season|2009–10 season]].{{cite web |title=Cleverley commits |url=http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~1880013,00.html |publisher=Watford F.C. |date=20 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121120433/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~1880013,00.html|archivedate=21 November 2009 |deadurl=yes}} Cleverley scored a further five goals in 20 appearances for Watford before a knee ligament injury in April 2010 ended his season prematurely.{{cite news |title=Watford midfielder Tom Cleverley out for season |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/watford/8610377.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=9 April 2010}} He went on to win the team's [[Watford F.C. Player of the Season|Player of the Season]] award.{{cite web |title=Player of the Season|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~2028625,00.html |publisher=Watford F.C. |date=18 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421030032/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~2028625,00.html|archivedate=21 April 2010 |deadurl=yes}} ====Wigan Athletic==== [[File:Tom Cleverley goal vs MLS All-Stars cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Cleverley playing for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 2010]] On 1 July 2010, Cleverley signed a new contract with the club, keeping him until 2013.{{cite news|title=Cleverley signs three year deal|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cleverley-signs-three-year-deal-893216|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=1 July 2010|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley returned to Manchester United for the beginning of the 2010–11 season, and travelled with the squad for their pre-season tour of North America in July 2010.{{cite news |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=Tour squad announced |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2010/Jul/Tour-squad-announced.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=9 July 2010 |accessdate=9 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013014658/http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2010/Jul/Tour-squad-announced.aspx|archivedate=13 October 2012 |deadurl=no}} He came on as a substitute for [[Ryan Giggs]] at half-time in the first match of the tour against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in Toronto, and scored United's third in a 3–1 win.{{cite news |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=Celtic 1 United 3 |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2010/Jul/Celtic-1-United-3.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=16 July 2012 |deadurl=yes }} He then netted his second of the tour on 28 July 2010, scoring United's fourth in their 5–2 win in the [[2010 MLS All-Star Game]]; he controlled [[Darren Fletcher]]'s flick into the box before lifting the ball over [[Wilman Conde]]'s head and side-footing it past [[Nick Rimando]].{{cite news |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=MLS All-Stars 2 United 5 |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2010/Jul/MLS-AllStars-2-United-5.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 August 2010, although Cleverley looked destined to stay with United for the season,{{cite news|title=Manchester United boss Sir Alex Feguson wants Premier League loans for youngsters Danny Welbeck and Tom Cleverley|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1296873/Danny-Welbeck-Tom-Cleverley-Premier-League-loan-moves.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=22 July 2010|accessdate=16 August 2016}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}} [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] confirmed they had agreed a season-long loan deal for Cleverley,{{cite web |title=Tom Clevlerley joins Roberto revolution |url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2140646,00.html |publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C. |date=31 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100903102401/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2140646,00.html|archivedate=3 September 2010 |deadurl=yes}} with Manchester United retaining the option to recall the player from his loan spell in January.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6630369,00.html |title=Latics fear Cleverley recall |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}} On 11 September 2010, Cleverley made his debut for Wigan which was also his [[Premier League]] debut, replacing [[Mauro Boselli]] in the 75th minute and assisting [[Antolin Alcaraz]] in a 1–1 home draw against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].{{cite news |first=Les |last=Roopanarine |title=Wigan 1–1 Sunderland|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8977470.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 September 2010 |accessdate=11 September 2010}} However, Cleverley suffered a knock, resulting a knee injury in training and was sidelined for weeks.{{cite news|title=Cleverley setback for Latics|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cleverley-setback-for-latics-899315|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=22 September 2010|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley then made his first-team return on 16 October 2010, coming on as a substitute for [[Ronnie Stam]] in the 79th minutes, in a 2–2 draw against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite news|title=Newcastle United 2–2 Wigan Athletic|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9093223.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 October 2010|accessdate=16 August 2016}} On 27 November, he scored his first goal for the club, also his first ever Premier League goal, in a 3–1 defeat away to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9221078.stm |title=West Ham 3–1 Wigan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2010 |accessdate=27 November 2010}} Seven days later he scored his second for Wigan and first home goal in a 2–2 draw against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite news |first=Julian |last=Shea |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9239609.stm |title=Wigan 2–2 Stoke |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 December 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2010}} However, following a [[Dubious Goals Committee|Dubious Goals Panel]] ruling, this goal was taken away from Cleverley and credited as a [[Rory Delap]] own goal.{{cite news |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Headlines/0,,12306~2361167,00.html |title=Dubious goals panel ruling |publisher=Premier League |date=16 May 2011 |accessdate=16 May 2011}} On 31 January 2011, Manchester United agreed to let Cleverley stay on loan at Wigan until the end of the season.{{cite news |first=Pete |last=O'Rourke |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6714155,00.html |title=Cleverley stays with Latics |publisher=Sky Sports |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}} Cleverley scored the decisive goal in a 2–1 away win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] which lifted Wigan out of the relegation zone.{{cite news |first=Jamie |last=Lillywhite |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9306174.stm |title=Wolverhampton 1–2 Wigan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 December 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2010}} However, Cleverley suffered a hamstring injury that kept him out for a month.{{cite news|title=Hull City vs Wigan Athletic: FA Cup Preview|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/hull-v-wigan-fa-cup-851185|newspaper=Manchester Evening News|date=7 January 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley then made his return from the first team on 5 February 2011, where he came on as a substitute for [[Victor Moses]] in the 67th minutes, in a 4–3 win over [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].{{cite news|title=Wigan Athletic 4–3 Blackburn Rovers|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9384149.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 February 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} After making return to the first team, Cleverley then scored and set up one of the goal, which turned out to be a winning goal, in a 2–1 win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on 19 March 2011.{{cite news|title=Wigan Athletic 2–1 Birmingham City|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9426720.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 March 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley was one of Wigan's stand-out performers, and ended the season with three goals and two assists in 25 Premier League appearances.{{cite web|title=Wigan Athletic 2010/11 Season|url= https://www.whoscored.com/Teams/194/Archive?stageId=4345|publisher=WhoScored.com}} ===Return to Manchester United=== ====2011–12 season==== [[Paul Scholes]]' retirement before the [[2011–12 Manchester United F.C. season|2011–12 season]] left an opening in Manchester United's central midfield. He came on as a second-half substitute for [[Michael Carrick]] after United went 2–0 down at half time, and assisted [[Nani]]'s equaliser, after a pass and move build up.{{cite news|title=Never write off Manchester United|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/man-city-vs-man-utd/235241|publisher=Sky Sports|date=7 August 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} [[File:Cleverly + welbeck.jpg|thumb|upright|Cleverley signing memorabilia alongside [[Danny Welbeck]] in 2011]] He started his first Premier League match for Manchester United on 14 August 2011, playing the full 90 minutes away to West Bromwich Albion in the first match of the 2011–12 season.{{cite news |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |title=West Brom 1–2 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14435075.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} After impressing in his opening match, Cleverley started Manchester United's second match of the campaign against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 22 August, getting an assist in the process.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He played the full match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 28 August 2011, which Manchester United won 8–2.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14606020|title=Manchester United 8–2 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 August 2011|accessdate=16 August 2016}} Cleverley sustained a ligament damage in his foot after being tackled heavily by Bolton's [[Kevin Davies]] in the 3rd minute of United's next match, a 5–0 away victory at Bolton Wanderers.[http://www.metro.co.uk/sport/875071-tom-cleverley-injury-overshadows-manchester-united-win-at-bolton "Tom Cleverley injury overshadows Manchester victory win at Bolton"]. {{cite news|title=Why Everton boss Koeman is discovering the limitations of the squad Martinez left him|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-boss-koeman-discovering-limitations-11997454|work=Liverpool Echo|date=8 October 2016|accessdate=22 October 2017}} Having have his first team limited to making five starts in twelve appearances without scoring, it was expected that Cleverley would leave the club in January{{cite news|title=Everton boss Koeman pondering Tom Cleverley January exit|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/everton-boss-koeman-pondering-tom-12392483|work=Liverpool Echo|date=1 January 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}}
{{cite news|title=Koeman to wield Everton axe on raft of players|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/koeman-wield-everton-axe-raft-12349733|work=Liverpool Echo|date=20 December 2016|accessdate=22 October 2017}} ===Return to Watford=== On 12 January 2017, Cleverley joined Premier League club Watford on loan until the end of the 2016–17 season, with a view to a permanent transfer, after failing to establish himself at Everton.{{cite news|title=Tom Cleverley: Everton midfielder joins Watford on loan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38593150|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 January 2017|accessdate=6 April 2017}} He re-debut for the club two days later, coming on as a second-half substitute, in a 0–0 draw against Middlesbrough.{{cite news|title=Watford 0 – 0 Middlesbrough|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38539448|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} He then played a vital role in the next two matches against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] and Arsenal.{{cite news|title=Benik Afobe earns point for Bournemouth in Watford draw|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/news/15039510.Benik_Afobe_earns_point_for_Bournemouth_in_Watford_draw/|work=Watford Observer|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}}
{{cite news|title=Sensational Watford stun Arsenal|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/15060860.Watford_pull_off_stunning_win_over_Arsenal/|work=Watford Observer|date=31 January 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} Having quickly made an impact for the side, it was announced on 31 March 2017 that Cleverley would join Watford permanently on 1 July on a five-year contract for an undisclosed fee.{{cite news|title=Watford exercise option to sign Tom Cleverley from Everton|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11686/10819249/watford-exercise-option-to-sign-tom-cleverley-from-everton|publisher=Sky Sports|date=31 March 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017}}
{{cite news|title=Walter Mazzarri would be 'very happy' to see Tom Cleverley make Watford move permanent from Everton|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/15084276.Mazzarri_eager_to_extend_Cleverley_s_Watford_stay/|work=Watford Observer|date=10 February 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} At the end of the 2016–17 season, Cleverley went on to make 17 appearances for the side. In the 2017–18 season, Cleverley continued to feature in the first team regularly following the managerial appointment of [[Marco Silva]] and was expected to face competition for a place in the side.{{cite news|title=Tom Cleverley enjoying 'different role' as Watford's most attacking midfielder|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/15546276.Cleverley_enjoying_attacking_midfield_role/|work=Watford Observer|date=20 September 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}}
{{cite news|title=EXCLUSIVE – Tom Cleverley credits Marco Silva for Watford's win over Arsenal and impressive start|url=https://talksport.com/football/exclusive-tom-cleverley-credits-marco-silva-watfords-win-over-arsenal-and-impressive-start|publisher=Talksport|date=16 October 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} It was not until on 15 October 2017 when he scored his first goal for Watford (his first for the side in seven years), in a 2–1 win over Arsenal.{{cite news|title=Watford 2 – 1 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41534302|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 October 2017|accessdate=22 October 2017}} ==International career== ===England U20=== Cleverley was called up to [[Noel Blake]]'s [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] for the first time on 12 March 2009. However, following a dislocated shoulder suffered while on loan at Leicester City a few days later, he was forced to withdraw from the squad, and was replaced by [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] midfielder [[Adam Clayton (footballer)|Adam Clayton]].{{cite news |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |title=Squad named for QPR On 12 October 2012, playing against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] in a World Cup qualifier, Cleverley made 165 touches during the match, the highest ever recorded for an England player.{{cite web|url=http://news.frrole.com/o/165---tom-cleverleys-165-touches-is-t-optajoe-london|title=165 – Tom Cleverley's 165 touches|publisher=FFRole News|date=12 October 2012|accessdate=16 August 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205164315/http://news.frrole.com/o/165---tom-cleverleys-165-touches-is-t-optajoe-london|archivedate=5 December 2013|deadurl=yes}} He also made two assists in the same match as England won 5–0.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/match-facts-england-v-san-marino-140910345.html|title=England put five past San Marino|publisher=Euro Sport|date=13 October 2012|accessdate=13 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015084134/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/match-facts-england-v-san-marino-140910345.html|archivedate=15 October 2012}} His 13th and last cap to date came in November 2013 against [[Germany national football team|Germany]].{{cite web|url=http://englandstats.com/players.php?pid=1187|title=Thomas William Cleverley|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate=5 October 2016}} ==Personal life== Growing up, Cleverley suffered from a childhood speech impediment and was given a nickname, "Chunks".
